member.name: T:Log4PostSharp.LogAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that each time a method is entered or left this fact will be written in the log.

remarks.para:
Logging can occur at any of the three stages of the method execution:
Before the control flow enters the method,
After the control flow exits the method after the method code is successfully executed,
After the control flow exits the method because its execution is interrupted by an uncaught exception.
Attribute defines properties for adjusting logging behavior (message severity and message text) for all these cases. Setting message severity (log level) to effectively disables logging for the specified case (i.e. respective logging code is not injected).

Logging message can contain placeholders which are expanded to actual values before the message is logged. Some of these values are already known during weaving, but others may vary between calls to the method and therefore can be determined only at run-time. Using the former ones has no impact on the performance of the injected code (i.e. performance is exactly same as if no placeholders were used), the latter, however, requires the Log4PostSharp to inject different, slower code.
Following table lists the placeholders which are expanded when the method is woven:

item.description: Expanded to method signature (not including namespaces of parameter types or return value type).

remarks.para: Following table lists the placeholders which are expanded at run-time and therefore their appearance causes the Log4PostSharp to inject slower code:

item.description: Expanded to the value of the specified parameter of the method.
Expanded to the comma-separated list of values of all parameters of the method. Value of every parameter is surrounded by quote-signs.
Expanded to the value that the method returns. For methods that return no value, is used.

remarks.para: Performance-wise, it does not make much of difference how many occurences of the "heavy" placeholders appear in a single message. What matters is that these are used at all. Also, messages for the same method are treated separately - using the "heavy" placeholders for the method entry message has no impact on the performance of the code injected for the exit or exception messages.
Because of some log4net API limitations, the "heavy" placeholders cannot be used in the . Code will fail to weave if this rule is broken.
